ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My writing improved greatly throughout the course, largely because the essay prompts all highlighted very different parts of the analytical process. This was incredibly helpful, as it forced me to explore different types of analysis and engage with texts on the micro and macro level. I gained a survey knowledge of American Literature (if that is even possible) and feel well established with my knowledge of the tradition. Reading all of the texts in conjunction with one another in a single umbrella course allowed me to place works in conversation that I would never have thought to otherwise. This highlighted salient themes across genres and caused me to question the creation of a canon.
A deep understanding of several texts within American Literature, skills to discuss and write about texts in relation to their contexts and other works, textual analysis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course is well structured in terms of assignments (in both spacing and range of subject). The texts themselves provided a wide range of content and were generally engaging. That being said, I think that, due to the necessarily fast paced nature of such a course, we did not always get as in depth in analysis/conversation in a given text as we could have. This makes sense when laying groundwork and trying to make sure that everyone understands the material, but sometimes it felt slightly rushed.

Strengths included the diverse range of interesting and powerful works in American literature that we read. Class discussions were always insightful and engaging, and the essay prompts were unique so students had to think creatively.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this class adjusted fairly well to virtual learning. The small class size lent itself to discussion and, despite the stiffness of a zoom meeting, people were fairly engaged in the subject matter. Additionally, Professor Williams's use of presentations, videos, and other virtual resources punctuated the calls in a nice way.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would, as I think it is a nice introduction/baseline to American literature. It is a good blend of literary analysis and contextualizing works in history. If my friend was generally interested in literature but did not have a concrete direction/area of interest I would recommend this as a way of sampling different genres and aspects of literature.

I would recommend this course! The reading list is diverse so you read a bit of poetry, short stories, memoirs, and a few novels from a range of authors. Professor Williams is enthusiastic and sets interesting essay prompts.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met via virtual seminar twice a week.
